tn.text: Paul reminds the believers that though idols have no power, believers must be careful not to affect the weaker believers who might think they care about the idols. He tells believers to be careful with the liberty believers have in Christ.
"We" means Paul and, though specifically writing to the Corinthian believers, includes all believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Paul uses this phrase to move on to the next question the Corinthians had asked him.

Gentile worshipers would offer grain, fish, fowl, or meat, to their gods. The priest would burn a portion of it on the altar. Paul is speaking of the portion the priest would give back for the worshiper to eat or sell in the market.

tn.ref: We know that "we all have knowledge."
tn.text: Paul is quoting a phrase that some Corinthians used. AT: "We all know, as you yourselves like to say, that 'we all have knowledge.'"

Paul speaks of what people know as if it were a person that can make another person larger than he should be. AT: "People who know much think that they are better than they really are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul speaks of love as if it were a person and helping people as if it were building a house. AT: "love truly helps people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"believes he knows everything about something"

tn.ref: that person is known by him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God knows that person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] )
"We" and "us" here refers to all believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: We know that "an idol in this world is nothing" and "that there is no God but one."
tn.text: Paul is probably quoting phrases that some Corinthians used. "We all know, as you yourselves like to say, that 'an idol has no power or meaning for us' and that, as you say, 'there is not God but one.'"

tn.ref: an idol in this world is nothing
tn.text: "an idol has no power in this world"
called gods** - "things that people call gods"
Paul does not believe that many gods and many lords exist, but he recognizes that the pagans believe they do.
"Whatever other people say or think, we believe that 'There is ... exist.'"

Paul is speaking here of "weak" brothers, people who cannot separate food sacrificed to idols from the worship of those idols. If a Christian eats food that has been sacrificed to an idol, weak brothers might think that God will allow them to worship the idol by eating the food. Even if the eater has not worshiped the idol and is simply eating the food, he has still corrupted his weak brothers' conscience.
"all people ... some people who are now Christians"
"ruined" or "harmed"

tn.ref: food will not present us to God
tn.text: Paul speaks of food as though it were a person who could make God welcome us. AT: "food does not give us favor with God" or "the food we eat does not make God pleased with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: We are not worse if we do not eat, nor better if we do eat it
tn.text: "Some people might think that if we do not eat some things, God will love us less. But they are wrong. Those who think that God will love us more if we do eat those things are also wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
believers not strong in their faith
Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so these words are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
what he understands to be right and wrong
"encouraged to eat"
Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so the word "your" here is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The brother or sister who is not strong in his or her faith will sin or lose his or her faith.
"Because what I have just said is true"
"Food" here is a metonym for the person eating the food. AT: "if I cause by eating" or "if I, because of what I eat, cause" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
